Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of integrated optical spectroscopy system at the Advanced Photon Source
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the acquisition of a shared-use, state-of-the-art combined Raman and optical spectroscopy system at the Advanced Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory (Chicago, IL). This new system will enable study of materials with unique physical and chemical properties, as well as novel technological materials, with advanced state-of-the-art techniques combined in a single instrument. This work has important implications to societal quality-of-life issues such as carbon sequestration, environmental remediation, properties of nanomaterials and earthquake generation. This work will also advance discovery and understanding by students as participants in the proposed research.

The availability of a system capable of concomitant in-situ X-ray diffraction and spectroscopy studies of materials at ambient and extreme pressure and temperature conditions (static and dynamic), including high spatial resolution studies of advanced and newly synthesized materials, will greatly enhance research capabilities of APS users. This instrumentation will enhance our understanding of planetary interiors by enabling studies of synthetic samples at the relevant conditions and of naturally-occurring minerals, rocks and their inclusions. Similarly, study of materials under conditions of high pressures and variable temperatures (low to very high) will be revealing for understanding of physical and chemical phenomena in condensed matter under extreme conditions including phase transitions and chemical reactions which provide a basis for synthesis of new materials under extreme conditions. Study of materials with reduced dimensionality, such as nanomaterials, will advance our understanding of their electronic and vibrational properties, crucial information for designing new advanced technology devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Raman and optical spectroscopy are versatile tools for characterization of a wide range of properties of Earth’s minerals and planetary materials and of materials of interest in science and technology. When applied in situ at extreme high pressure and temperature conditions in laser heated diamond anvil cells (DAC), these techniques become vital for understanding the structure, composition, and evolution of terrestrial and giant planets, and also for deciphering complex properties of advanced materials for practical applications. Here we report on the construction a conceptually new, user-friendly, integrated system for worldwide users at APS.  

We created a shared, state-of-the-art, user-friendly integrated Raman and optical spectroscopy system at the Sector 13 (GeoSoilEnviroCARS) of the Advanced Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory (Chicago, IL). The system enables concomitant in-situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction and spectroscopy (XES, NFS) and optical spectroscopy studies of materials at ambient and extreme pressure and temperature conditions (static and dynamic) including high spatial resolution studies of advanced and newly synthesized materials. It is now in use by a number of investigators (more than 50) from high-pressure and material science communities.

The system features the following:

- Raman spectroscopy (free-standing and in the DAC) with five excitation wavelengths (266, 473, 532, 660, 946 nm)
- double sided IR laser heating combined with high temperature Raman and Coherent Anti-Stokes Raman Spectroscopy (CARS)

- low-temperature Raman and CARS spectroscopy
- transient (based on a bright supercontinuum light source) spectroscopy in a wide
spectral range (200-1600 nm) (under construction)
- confocal imaging (under construction)

The system has been used in several experiments where measurements of Raman spectra concomitantly with on line XRD data collection was necessary. Also, the system has been used by scientists from the Center of Nanoscale Materials (APS).

A number of young researchers have been trained to Raman and optical spectroscopy techniques.

The Raman/optical spectroscopy system, which we had built, will enable in situ and ex situ studies of materials subjected to extreme pressure-temperature conditions and of newly synthesized advanced materials. These studies are complementary and synergistic to X-ray diffraction and spectroscopy available at APS beamlines.
The major research topics include:
- In situ characterization of a wide range of properties of minerals at extreme high P-T conditions relevant to planetary deep interiors, essential for understanding the structure, composition, and evolution of terrestrial and giant planets.
- Study of physical and chemical properties of naturally occurring minerals, rocks and their inclusions (e.g. meteorites), as well as recovered after high P-T experiments samples to understand the nature of planetary environments and experimental physicochemical processes.

Other research area include:
- In situ study of materials under conditions of high pressures and variable temperatures (low to very high) that is revealing for understanding of physical and chemical phenomena in condensed matter under extreme conditions. This includes physical and chemical transformations which provide a basis for synthesis of new materials under extreme conditions.
- Study of materials with reduced dimensionality including nanomaterials at high pressures probing the stress, structural, and compositional dependencies of the electronic and vibrational properties, which are crucial for designing of new advanced technology devices.
